Triggering Event: A canvas lay untouched in the corner of her studio, its pristine white mocking her creative block. She had spent hours mixing colors, cleaning brushes, anything to delay facing the blank expanse. The ticking clock echoed her growing frustration, each second amplifying the gnawing feeling that she was losing her touch.
Generated Assessment: **Fucking Great, Just What I Needed** Oh, wow. This is just fantastic. I get to spend my entire day staring at a blank canvas because I'm too scared to even pick up a brush. The fact that I've wasted so much time procrastinating means I'll probably have to work double-time when I finally decide to start painting again. And who knows how long it will take? Maybe I'll be like this forever. Fuck it, let's just say I'm going to paint something today. Not tomorrow or next week, but today. It's not like it's going to magically come together or anything, but hey, maybe it will. *Sigh* Yeah, right. Whatever. I guess I'm going to try anyway. I mean, what's the worst that could happen? I fail? That's okay; I can always blame it on someone else later. If anyone asks, I'll tell them that I didn't actually put in the effort because I was "too busy." Or if they keep pushing me, I can just tell them that I'm "working on my inspiration" and won't give up until then. fuck this shit, let's get started already! ​

Triggering Event: A slow, drizzling rain began as she locked up the empty storefront at 10 pm, her reflection in the glass a stark reminder of the lonely life reflected back at her. The once bustling retail space now echoed with silence, save for the distant hum of the occasional car driving by on the wet street outside. She pulled her worn coat tighter around herself as she stepped out into the rain, the chill seeping into her bones like an unwelcome companion. As she walked to her car, she noticed a group of teenage girls laughing and huddling together under an awning nearby, their laughter ringing hollow in her ears. She couldn't remember the last time she had shared such carefree moments with friends, let alone felt young enough to laugh so freely. The weight of her years and her solitude seemed heavier than ever as she slid into her car, the rain tapping a mournful rhythm on its roof.
Generated Assessment: Oh, fucking great. Another night spent shivering and walking alone through the pouring rain. It's just another day of me getting fucked over again, isn't it? Why does this always have to happen? I swear, if I was supposed to get hurt, then why the fuck doesn't it happen when I'm actually having fun? Or better yet, when I'm surrounded by people who don't want to kill themselves every five minutes? But no, it has to happen right in front of me, reminding me of all the things I'll never experience. What's worse is how these teenagers seem to be enjoying each other's company, laughing and having a good time. They're probably doing everything they're supposed to be doing—going out with friends, being social, enjoying life—while I'm stuck here alone, wasting away. Why can't I be one of them? Why does it always have to be me? And what's with the weather anyway? Rainy nights like this are supposed to bring us closer together, aren't they? Instead, I'm left feeling more isolated than ever, while everyone else gets to enjoy the comfort of a dry, warm home. Of course, that's exactly what I'm supposed to feel—the pain of loneliness. Triggering Event: An elderly woman, a retired teacher, sits alone in her quiet apartment, flipping through old photographs from her teaching days. She sighs, her brows furrowed with worry as she pauses at a picture of a former student who had struggled academically but never sought help, fearing it would reflect badly on him. She worries about his future, wondering if he'll ever understand the importance of asking for assistance when needed. Her mind races with thoughts of all the students she couldn't reach, those she feared she'd failed. She picks up her phone to call him, but hesitates, her fingers hovering over the dial button, afraid that after all these years, he might not want to hear from her.
Generated Assessment: It's just so frustrating to see this young man struggle with his education. He's always been so bright, full of potential, yet somehow he's fallen behind. I wish there was something I could have done differently to support him better. Maybe if I'd seen some early warning signs, I could've reached out sooner, helped him get back on track. But now, it feels like too late. His grades are slipping, and I fear he may never catch up. It's heartbreaking to think that he might not realize how much he needs our guidance. Every time I look at him, I feel a sense of responsibility. As his teacher, I feel like I'm failing him, even though I know I did everything I could. The thought of what could have been—of the good grades, of the college acceptance, of the successful career—heaven forbid!—it's almost unbearable. My mind keeps replaying all the times we spent together, the lessons I taught, the encouragement I gave, and now it's all coming crashing down. If only I'd known earlier... Perhaps if I'd acted sooner, things wouldn't be this bad. I keep thinking about the other students I've taught, those who did ask for help when they needed it, and how they turned their lives around. Triggering Event: She sits at her desk, fingers hovering over the keyboard, staring blankly at the lines of code she's written a thousand times before. The hum of her home office, usually soothing, now feels oppressive. Her husband's footsteps echo down the hall, pausing outside her door. "I'm heading out," he calls, his voice casual yet distant. She wants to reply, but the words stick in her throat. Another day alone, another problem unsolved. The helplessness washes over her like a tidal wave, paralyzing her limbs and drowning her thoughts.

She felt her face grow warm as she realized it was her own husband they were talking about.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

He watches her giggle over the counter, his coworker, as she bags groceries for an elderly woman who's taking too long to decide between brands of cat food. He rolls his eyes, muttering under his breath about entitled seniors and useless laughter. She glances at him, smiles, then turns back to the customer, her voice sugary sweet. His jaw clenches, a sneer pulling at his lips as he thinks, "She's just kissing ass for a bigger tip."
Generated Assessment: "I can't stand how smug she is. I bet she thinks she's so much better than everyone else because she gets tips from rich people. Meanwhile, I'm stuck here with all these losers working hard but barely making ends meet." "Yeah, it's annoying when they take forever, especially when you're trying to make your shift end. But honestly, it makes me feel like a loser too. I wish I could be more patient." "I don't know what's worse—her fake smile or the way she treats us like we're beneath her. I mean, she's clearly only smiling because she wants a big tip, right? It’s ridiculous that she has such a big personality when most of our customers are boring old men who think they own the place." “You’re being really insensitive again, aren’t you? I know you love going out with rich people and pretending you care about them. Just leave the poor guy alone and let him enjoy his cheap cat food.” "I guess I am getting frustrated, but I wouldn’t call it smug. Maybe I’m just tired of dealing with difficult customers. But yeah, it would be nice if she wasn’t so snooty, acting like she’s better than everyone else just because she works here. And honestly, I’ve noticed that some of my coworkers act pretentious too, which makes me wonder if there’s something wrong with me."

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her classroom after hours, she noticed a small, dusty footprint leading from the window to her desk. She was certain she'd locked up before leaving yesterday. Her heart pounded as she inspected the room, every shadow seeming to conceal an unseen observer. The faint scent of cologne, familiar yet unfamiliar, hung in the air. She reached for her phone, trembling fingers dialing security.

Triggering Event: On his way home from a late shift, he noticed a parked car across the street from their house, windows tinted despite the darkness. The engine was off, but the silhouette of someone behind the wheel made him uneasy. He had seen that make and model before, in reports from a recent string of burglaries. His heart pounding, he pulled out his flashlight and approached the car, hand on his gun. As he reached for the door handle, the engine suddenly roared to life, tires screeching as it sped off into the night.
Generated Assessment: fuckin asshole just speeding away from my fucking front yard with my fucking family inside. I was so close to catching this fucker too, just had to get my ass on the curb for the window to roll down and see what the fuck he was doing there. He was probably here looking for valuables, maybe even breaking in right now as I type this. That’s why I’m calling 911. They’ll send someone over ASAP. I hope they catch the son of a bitch and bring him in. If he’s still around, I’ll be waiting by the door with my shotgun ready. I don’t know how much longer I can hold back. This is getting old. We’ve been dealing with these thieves since January, and every time it feels like we’re one step closer to being victims ourselves. My wife deserves better than this. She works hard, always has. Triggering Event: "Arriving at the office, he found his editor had sent out an email to everyone regarding his latest article, subject line: 'Further Edits Needed - Please Review'. His inbox was flooded with sympathetic replies, each one a subtle reminder of his oversight."
Generated Assessment: **Blame Shifted: A Cognitive Distortion** * **Cognitive Dissonance**: The feeling of discomfort arises from the discrepancy between our actions and expectations. * **Emotional Incongruence**: Our emotions are inconsistent with our thoughts, leading to feelings of guilt or shame. * **Self-Deception**: We deny or rationalize our mistakes, avoiding accountability and personal growth. When faced with criticism, we often resort to blaming others to maintain self-esteem and avoid emotional discomfort. This defense mechanism involves shifting the focus away from ourselves, making it easier to accept failure. However, this approach can hinder personal development and relationships. In the given situation, the individual's response to their editor's email reveals a deeper issue: > "He felt like he'd been punched in the gut, but instead of crying, he chose to send an angry reply to the entire staff." (From [the original post](https://www.reddit.com/r/AmITheAsshole/comments/gn0g8k/aait_for_sendng_an_angry_email_to_the_entire/)) This statement suggests that he is attempting to deflect attention from himself by directing anger toward others. By doing so, he avoids confronting the true cause of his frustration – the fear of being judged or criticized. While it may seem more comfortable to shift the blame onto others, this behavior prevents us from addressing the root problem. Triggering Event: In the dim light of her kitchen, she stood over the sink, scrubbing her hands raw under scalding water. The clock's tick echoed like a countdown in the otherwise silent house. A worn photo of their smiling faces at the beach last summer caught her eye - now a bittersweet reminder of happier times. Her husband, uncharacteristically quiet upstairs, had retreated to bed hours ago, his silence heavier than any argument. She knew what tomorrow would bring: another empty chair at breakfast, another day of pretending everything was fine. As she turned off the tap, the sudden stillness felt like a suffocating blanket, and she struggled to catch her breath.

It's all just too much. I'm not saying it's wrong, but it feels incredibly unfair considering how much he's been cheating on you.
